unnormalised: Cybersecurity firm, SecurIT Solutions, reported a 25% increase in ransomware attacks targeting Indian businesses in Q3 2024. The report highlighted that the manufacturing and healthcare sectors were particularly vulnerable, with demands ranging from ₹5 lakh to ₹50 lakh. Experts are advising companies to update their systems and implement multi-factor authentication (MFA).
normalised: Cybersecurity firm, Secur-I-T Solutions, reported a twenty five percent increase in ransomware attacks targeting Indian businesses in Q-three two thousand and twenty four. The report highlighted that the manufacturing and healthcare sectors were particularly vulnerable, with demands ranging from rupee five lakh to rupee fifty lakh. Experts are advising companies to update their systems and implement multi-factor authentication (M-F-A).

unnormalised: According to the report, 60% of the attacks originated from IP addresses in China and Russia. SecurIT Solutions CEO, Mr. Rakesh Verma, emphasized the importance of employee training in identifying phishing emails. He noted that many attacks still succeed because employees click on malicious links, often disguised as official communications. One notable incident involved a major hospital chain, Fortis Healthcare, which experienced a data breach affecting over 10,000 patients' records on 15/08/2024.

unnormalised: The CERT-In (Indian Computer Emergency Response Team) has issued an advisory urging organizations to strengthen their cybersecurity posture. They recommend regular vulnerability assessments and penetration testing (VAPT). The advisory also suggests backing up critical data offline and implementing incident response plans to minimize the impact of potential attacks. The cyber security helpline number is 1930.
